> , should we use HWSKU + topo to define lossy HW? I would think same HWSKU could use for lossless scenario also, so this assumption maybe not true in that case?

these hwsku don't have lossless buffer defined in the /usr/share/sonic/device/\<platform>/\<hwsku> directory. so they cannot be used for lossless scenario. Currently, we don't have the scenario of using both lossless and lossy topo on same HWSKU, so should be fine. We can leave it for the future when the requirement comes in.

master/202411 has this python3 environment, and we only change those two branches.

@StormLiangMS Confirmed with Broadcom in CS00012398710 that TH5 moved to yml format, so we no longer can dump the file from bcm shell.

@Javier-Tan, wondering what's the conflict here, how this kubesonic test iptables rule affects the cacl/test_cacl_application.py, just want to know that is it possible to cause any issue in production when these two features are both enabled.

@lixiaoyuner the leftover iptables from kubernetes test are unexpected in cacl test:

The Kubernetes iptable generated rules are generated during this command https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/bacd336b1b7a4d39217ddba9bf3cde96ac4716ee/tests/kubesonic/test_k8s_join_disjoin.py#L353 which has a proper teardown, but it doesn't get rid of the iptable rules

cacl test checks against a set of expected iptable rules https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/bacd336b1b7a4d39217ddba9bf3cde96ac4716ee/tests/cacl/test_cacl_application.py#L1081 

Which are generated by https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/bacd336b1b7a4d39217ddba9bf3cde96ac4716ee/tests/cacl/test_cacl_application.py#L497

I've had a search about removing the kubernetes generated iptable rules but it seems there is no straightforward way of doing it.

@liuh-80 Do you have an ADO number? #Closed

can we get rid of the older logs by checked timestamp, when count lines of such syslog?
I'm ok with this change, but it'll add runtime overall for 2 sec per device

> @liuh-80 Do you have an ADO number?

Fixed, updated ADO number to PR description.

> can we get rid of the older logs by checked timestamp, when count lines of such syslog? I'm ok with this change, but it'll add runtime overall for 2 sec per device

Log count is not accurate, because journalctl log may rotate, if there is only 1 log left and timestamp are exactly same, it's impossible to identify.

Hi @Verma-Anukul,

Thanks for the update. I have a couple of minor suggestions:

Conditional NTP Setup:
Even if the DUT is already synchronized with the NTP server, this implementation always performs the NTP configuration. Could we add a check to determine whether synchronization is actually required before proceeding? I believe the function check_dut_timestamp in conftest.py already performs a similar check, and it might be beneficial to leverage that here to avoid unnecessary reconfiguration.

Test Coverage:
Could you please mention which topologies you’ve tested this change on?

Note: The reason for introducing this NTP setup is not directly related to PR #17010.
The primary motivation is to ensure that the DUT's system time is in sync with the NTP server, as discrepancies can lead to failures in gNMI server certificate validation due to invalid time ranges.

Thanks!

> Hi @Verma-Anukul,
> 
> Thanks for the update. I have a couple of minor suggestions:
> 
> Conditional NTP Setup: Even if the DUT is already synchronized with the NTP server, this implementation always performs the NTP configuration. Could we add a check to determine whether synchronization is actually required before proceeding? I believe the function check_dut_timestamp in conftest.py already performs a similar check, and it might be beneficial to leverage that here to avoid unnecessary reconfiguration.
> 
> Test Coverage: Could you please mention which topologies you’ve tested this change on?
> 
> Note: The reason for introducing this NTP setup is not directly related to PR #17010. The primary motivation is to ensure that the DUT's system time is in sync with the NTP server, as discrepancies can lead to failures in gNMI server certificate validation due to invalid time ranges.
> 
> Thanks!

@YatishSVC 
Thanks for suggestions 

Conditional NTP Setup: Added check for NTP sync status before setup

 Test Coverage: Verified on T0 & T1 setup

Yes, I had found that, for Certificate validation system time should be proper

> @qiluo-msft @ganglyu I addressed one issue with the test due to authentication changes coming from newly added test cases. However, the test still fails. I can see from the logs that the gnmi server on the device receives an Update list instead of a Replace list:
> 
> ```
> I0501 18:52:44.385066 777 server.go:608] Update path: path:{elem:{name:"CONFIG_DB"} elem:{name:"localhost"}}
> ```
> 
> This is the error I would expect if the fix added in [sonic-net/sonic-buildimage#22355](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22355) is not being pulled in. Is there a way to verify whether those changes are being used for these test runs? If so, then there is presumably some issue with the tool fix and I'll need to investigate further. If not, how can we ensure these test runs are using the most up-to-date version of the toolchain?

I pulled the latest PTF docker container (`docker pull sonicdev-microsoft.azurecr.io/docker-ptf:latest`) and verified that the changes from https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22355 are there. I also verified that when the test runs using the modified gnxi script it passes successfully. So the test is valid, and the change to the gnxi tool is valid, and the modified gnxi tool is available in the latest `docker-ptf` container, but somehow the ElasticTest system is not using the correct PTF container. I think that container is getting set here https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/03fdac29192c59c404cce87d3c132763e151f23f/tests/pipelines/cont-warmboot.yml#L122 but I can't quite tell how that's working as I'm not familiar with the ElasticTest platform. It seems like it creates a unique PTF container for each test run, based off of a build number. @qiluo-msft @ganglyu @dt-nexthop @bhouse-nexthop any thoughts on this?

@anders-nexthop can you verify https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/03fdac29192c59c404cce87d3c132763e151f23f/azure-pipelines.yml#L86-L104 which is choosing between tag `py3only` and `latest`, that the `py3only` container actually has your changes too? I wonder if `py3only` isn't being updated any more since sonic-buildimage switched to *always* being `SONIC_PTF_ENV_PY_VER=py3` as per https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22409. As if now days only the `latest` ptf is being built that would explain the error.

You can see from the test case failure link that it chose the `py3only` image and not `latest`: https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build/results?buildId=840347&view=logs&j=8b5da791-4df5-594e-e5e0-050f075410e7&t=0f13ada6-c985-5b90-1caa-4ec6d72aa24a&l=11

> @anders-nexthop can you verify
> 
> https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/03fdac29192c59c404cce87d3c132763e151f23f/azure-pipelines.yml#L86-L104
> 
> which is choosing between tag `py3only` and `latest`, that the `py3only` container actually has your changes too? I wonder if `py3only` isn't being updated any more since sonic-buildimage switched to _always_ being `SONIC_PTF_ENV_PY_VER=py3` as per [sonic-net/sonic-buildimage#22409](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/22409). As if now days only the `latest` ptf is being built that would explain the error.
> You can see from the test case failure link that it chose the `py3only` image and not `latest`: https://dev.azure.com/mssonic/build/_build/results?buildId=840347&view=logs&j=8b5da791-4df5-594e-e5e0-050f075410e7&t=0f13ada6-c985-5b90-1caa-4ec6d72aa24a&l=11

I have verified that `py3only` container does not have my changes. The container image seems pretty outdated:

```
(venv) [anders@ds103 sonic-mgmt]$ docker image ls | grep docker-ptf
sonicdev-microsoft.azurecr.io/docker-ptf latest a2c7195a00b2 27 hours ago 1.52GB
sonicdev-microsoft.azurecr.io/docker-ptf py3only c13e69685c39 2 months ago 1.51GB
```

It seems like it would be enough to rebuild `py3only` and push an updated container image. @qiluo-msft do you know how we would go about updating `py3only` container in the registry?
pretty sure `latest` is really only py3 now days, right? So maybe the better approach is to modify the azure pipeline to never use the `:py3only` image anymore.
